questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analog called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for the differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium is optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.
  • An enhanced whole-body CT study is done, which takes 60-70 seconds. Following this, a whole-body PET imaging, takes about 30-45 minutes to complete.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early sign of malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is a late sign of malignant hyperthermia.

Malignant hyperthermia is an emergent condition that occurs in susceptible individuals when they are exposed to an inhaled anesthetic agent (isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane) or succinylcholine.

Clinical manifestations of malignant hyperthermia:

Early Signs:

  • Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide
  • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
  • Masseter spasm, if succinylcholine has been used
  • Generalized muscle rigidity
  • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
  • Profuse sweating
  • Mottling of skin
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Unstable blood pressure

Late Signs:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rapid increase of core body temperature- body temperature rises by 1°C every 5 minutes
  • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
  • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and diameter of D and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering the flow is laminar through both the cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A?
questions.solution:
Flow through B will be 8 times more than the flow through A. 

According to Poiseuille Hagen formula,

F= ΔP x π/8 x 1/n x r4/L 

F = flow

ΔP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

η = viscosity

r = radius of the tube

L = length of the tube

Hence flow directly varies to the 4th power of radius and inversely varies to length. 

Flow through B = (2r)4/2L = 8 times

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be given along with levodopa?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa (when not combined with carbidopa) by enhancing its peripheral decarboxylation so that less of it remains available to cross to the brain.

Drug interactions of levodopa

  • Pyridoxine: Abolishes the therapeutic effect of levodopa 
  • Phenothiazines, butyrophenones, and metoclopramide reverse the therapeutic effect of levodopa by blocking DA receptors
  • Nonselective MAO inhibitors along with levodopa may cause a hypertensive crisis
  • Antihypertensive drugs accentuate the postural hypotension caused by levodopa
  • Antiparkinsonian anticholinergic drugs have additive therapeutic action with low doses of levodopa, but retard its absorption—more time is available for peripheral degradation—efficacy of levodopa may be reduced.

Related Pearl: Medical treatment of Parkinson's disease

To increase dopamine Anti cholinergics

Dopamine precursor       

 Anti muscarinic
Levodopa Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl)
Dopa decarboxylase inhibitor Benztropine
Carbedopa Procyclidine
Benserazide H1 antagonist
Dopamine agonist-Ergot derivatives Promethazine
Bromocriptine Orphenadrine
Cabergoline Diphenhydramine
Pergolide  
Lisuride  
Dopamine agonist-Non ergot derivatives  
Ropinirole  
Pramipexole  
Rotigotine  
Apomorphine  
Dopamine facilitator  
Amantadine  
MAO-B inhibitor  
Selegiline  
Rasagiline  
COMT inhibitor  
Tolcapone  
Entacapone

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was on crutches for a few months after a road traffic accident. After the initial 2 weeks, he complained of an inability to extend his wrist. He achieved complete recovery a few weeks later. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man not able to extend his wrist after the use of a crutch and complete recovery after a few weeks is suggestive of crutch palsy which is a type of neurapraxia. 

Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Some types of sensation and muscle power are lost in neuropraxia. The structure of the nerve is not changed and there is complete, spontaneous recovery after a few weeks. Neurapraxia occurs due to segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure. 

Crutch palsy occurs when the radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object (crutch). Other examples of neuropraxia include Saturday night palsy and tourniquet palsy.

Other options:

Option A: Neurotmesis occurs due to the damage in both axon and nerve by a complete section or scarring of a segment in open fractures. A surgical nerve repair is required since spontaneous recovery doesn't take place.

Option B: Axonotmesis occurs due to the damage of axons with preservation of the internal architecture of the nerve. It is seen typically after closed fractures and dislocations. Spontaneous recovery can occur but may take a long time.

Option C: Neurolysis is the surgical removal of fibrotic tissue inside a nerve trunk.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A patient is prepped for a minor procedure in the ophthalmology outpatient department. The following instruments are assembled in the tray. Which of the following glands is involved in the pathology for which this procedure is performed?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments represent the "Chalazion set" which is used to perform incision and curettage of a chalazion. A chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the meibomian gland. 

The chalazion clamp is specific to the incision and curettage of a chalazion which consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation. A chalazion scoop/curette is another instrument specific to the incision and curettage of a chalazion. Other instruments are non-specific to the chalazion set. 

A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands. It is also known as a tarsal cyst or meibomian cyst. Retention of the meibomian gland secretions may sometimes lead to a similar granulomatous reaction. A chalazion may be single or multiple. Patients present with painless swelling away from the lid margin. The upper eyelid is more commonly involved. They may reduce in size, but the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur. 

Treatment of chalazion includes injection of intralesional triamcinolone or curettage.

The image given below shows the chalazion.

Other options :

Options A and D: The gland of Wolfring and gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands and are not involved in a chalazion.

Option B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

The picture below shows a stye/hordeolum externum -

questions.text: The image shown below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exclamation mark hair sign which is a characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes nonscarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients.

The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with telogen effluvium demonstrate empty follicles and regrowing hairs of normal thickness on dermoscopy.

Option C: Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with this disease present with lustreless, dry, short hair. On trichoscopy, patients may have a characteristic bamboo hair defect due to the collapse of the distal hair shaft into the proximal hair shaft secondary to defective keratinization.

Option D: Primary cicatricial alopecias are inflammatory disorders that lead to permanent hair loss

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation. His erect X-ray abdomen is as shown. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 64-year-old man with severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and obstipation along with the radiograph showing the coffee bean sign is likely to be sigmoid volvulus.

Sigmoid volvulus is a condition that occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.

A sigmoid volvulus can be differentiated from a cecal volvulus by swirl sign, location of the obstructed loop, and anatomical appendages. The swirl with sigmoid volvulus is located on the right quadrant while the swirl with cecal volvulus is located at the pelvic brim. 

Other options:

Option B: Colonic diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. The barium enema given below shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth. 

Option C: Cecal volvulus is more common in females in the 4th to 5th decade. It is characterized by ischemia. 

Option D: Paralytic ileus occurs secondary to neuromuscular failure. This leads to the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. It mainly occurs following laparotomy. The image given below is an X-ray of a patient with a paralytic ileus.

Differences between the small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

Features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis.

Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady complained of increased sensitivity to certain odors. Which of the following nerves is unlikely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is a purely motor cranial nerve and is not involved in olfaction.

The other three cranial nerves— trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves—are mixed cranial nerves and contribute to olfaction.

Vagal nerve stimulation modifies the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

FUNCTIONAL COMPONENT  CRANIAL NERVES

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibres, have the GVE component.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. She gives a similar history of hearing loss to her mother.  The otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes are given below. The pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curves bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is active otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in a noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. The otoscopic picture shows a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, called the Schwartze sign. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to hasten the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is surgical, that includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

Audiogram given below shows Cahart's notch seen in otosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120-155 dB such as explosions, gunshots etc, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz.

Option C: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear that arises from the glomus bodies. When the tumor is intratympanic, the hearing loss is a conductive type and a swishing, pulsatile tinnitus that is synchronous with the carotid pulse is heard. On otoscopic examination, a red reflex through the tympanic membrane is seen. This is known as the 'rising sun' appearance.

Option D: Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

Middle ear pathology (stapes footplate)

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 syndrome.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Inhibin B is not a component assayed under the quad-screening test. Dimeric inhibin-A is evaluated in this screening test.

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol (E3)
  • Dimeric inhibin A

The following table summarizes the findings of the quad-screening test in various conditions.

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

questions.text: A new screening test for detecting cervical cancer is being studied in a group of 100 women.  60 women tested negative and 40 tested positive.  Among the women who were tested positive by the new test 30 were actually positive and among the women who tested negative, 10 were having the disease. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value is 75%

The data given in the question is tabulated as follows:

  Diseased Not diseased Total
Test positive 30 (TP) 10 (FP) 40
Test negative 10 (FN) 50 (TN) 60
Total 40 60 100

TP - True positive, FP - False positive, FN - False negative, TN - True negative.

Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

Here PPV = 30/(30+10) x 100 = 30/40 x 100 = 75%

Predictive value of a positive test:

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. It is highly related to the prevalence of a disease. The predictive value of a positive test will be more accurate if the disease is more prevalent and vice-versa.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses _____ as its secondary messenger.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin acting on its V2 receptor uses cAMP as its secondary messenger.

Vasopressin is a nonapeptide hormone that is synthesized in the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary. Vasopressin plays a vital role in controlling the body's osmotic balance, blood pressure regulation, and sodium homeostasis.

Vasopressin acts on

  • V1 receptor to cause vasoconstriction using calcium as its secondary messenger.
  • V2 receptor to facilitate reabsorption of water through aquaporin 2, primarily in the collecting ducts, using cAMP as its secondary messenger.
  • Thus, vasopressin acts on g-protein coupled receptors using different secondary messengers to accomplish its various actions.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A and D
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
 
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Parathyroid hormone
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through JAK-STAT or MAP kinase pathway Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis. The maternal condition that can give rise to this condition in the baby is pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes.

Poorly controlled diabetes, both preconceptionally and in early pregnancy, is thought to cause this malformation. HbA1c levels correlate with the malformations. Instead, a macrosomic infant is commonly seen in gestational diabetes.

Other options:

Option B- In gestational diabetes, the risk of fetal anomalies is not increased. This is due to the absence of metabolic disturbance during organogenesis

Option C- Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.

Option D- ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placental tissue invading the myometrium of the uterus suggestive of placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity is increased in the fed state?
questions.solution:
The activity of the enzyme glycogen synthase is increased in the fed state.

Glycogen functions as the secondary long-term energy storage, with the primary energy stores being fats held in adipose tissue. Hence, glycogen synthesis/glycogenesis activity is increased in the fed state. Glycogenesis takes place majorly in the skeletal muscle and the liver.

Metabolic changes that take place in fasting and fed states:

Metabolic process

Fasting state/ low insulin-glucagon ratio

Fed state/ high insulin-glucagon ratio

Gluconeogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenolysis

Increased

Decreased

Ketogenesis

Increased

Decreased

Glycogenesis

Decreased

Increased

Glucose 6-phosphate derived from glycogen breakdown can

  • Be used as a fuel for glycolysis in muscles,
  • Be converted into free glucose in the liver and subsequently released into the blood, and
  • Enter into the the pentose phosphate pathway to generate NADPH or ribose in a variety of tissues.

Other options:

Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option B: HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option D: Pyruvate carboxylase is the enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis. It converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate. Its levels are decreased in the fed state.

Related Pearl: Steps in Glycogenesis & Respective Enzymes

Steps

Enzymes

Glucose Phosphorylation

Hexokinase in Muscle

Glucokinase in Liver

Glucose-6-PO4 to Glucose-1-PO4 conversion

Phosphoglucomutase

Attachment of UTP to Glucose-1-PO4

UDP Glucose Pyrophosphorylase

Attachment of UDP-Glucose to Glycogen Primer (Glycogenin)

Glycogen initiator synthase

Glycogen synthesis

Glycogen synthase

Glycogen Branches formation

Branching enzyme (amylo-[1—4]—>[1—6]-transglucosidase)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary.

Pharmalogical treatment can be divided into abortive treatment of acute attackes and prophylaxis to prevent actue attacks. Acute attack can be treated with acetaminophen, aspirin NSAIDs, antiemetics and triptans. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) are used in moderate to severe migraine or when simple analgesics have not been effective. Prophylaxis with beta blockers like propranalol, valproate, topiramate.

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies using CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor are effective in treating and preventing migraine. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At Least 2 of the following features

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at Least 1 of the following features

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A child with a fever and rash was brought to your OPD. Oral findings as shown in the image were observed. During which period is the disease communicable to others?

choices.text: Before as well as after the appearance of rash.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing koplik spots is suggestive of measles. It is communicable before as well as after the appearance of rash.

Measles, otherwise known as rubeola, is caused by the paramyxovirus which is an RNA virus. The virus has an incubation period of 10 to 14 days. It is a droplet infection and the period of communicability ranges from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of the rash. 

The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomonic Koplik spots. Koplik spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa at the level of the premolars.

This is followed by the appearance of a characteristic dusky red maculopapular rash that begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

The diagnosis of measles infection is mainly clinical but may be confirmed by serological demonstration of serum IgM antibodies. 

The management is mainly supportive in form of relieving common symptoms such as fever, cough, and nasal congestion and providing adequate nutritional support.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

 

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

 

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

Measles

 

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

 

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

Polio

 

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

 

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

 

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

 

Until swelling subsides.

Pertussis

 

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

Meningococcal meningitis

 

Until first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

Streptococcal pharyngitis

 

Until first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He cites the influenza pandemic as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The influenza pandemic is an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years. Influenza pandemics are known to occur at intervals of 7- 10 years, due to antigenic variations. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to protect communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is a type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario and image of a patient with abdominal distension, jaundice, pruritus, and neutrophil count >650 per mm3, the likely diagnosis is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.  

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever, and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis, and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis.

Other options:

Option B: Malignant ascites occurs as a complication of intra-abdominal and extra-abdominal malignancies. Patients can present with increasing abdominal girth, generalized abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. Weight loss may be more common. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a milky or bloody appearance with elevated levels of tumor markers and VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor). Treatment is by paracentesis and peritoneovenous shunt.

Option C: Ascites is often seen in patients with tubercular peritonitis. Multiple tubercles are seen on the peritoneum. Ascitic fluid analysis reveals a straw-colored fluid with a white blood cell count >500 mm3. Laparoscopy and peritoneal biopsy may be helpful in diagnosis. Management is by supportive and anti-tubercular therapy.  

Option D: Intestinal obstruction can present as pain, abdominal distension, vomiting, and absolute constipation. Abdominal radiographs taken in a supine position are useful in diagnosis. Abdominal radiograph in erect posture shows fluid levels. Management is mainly by insertion of a nasogastric tube, replacement of fluid and electrolytes, and surgery.

questions.text: An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

choices.text: The hernia may spontaneously resolve by 2 years of age
Surgical repair is indicated if the hernia persists for more than 5 years of age
Strangulation is a common complication associated with this type of hernia
Mayo’s procedure or mesh repair can be done for this hernia

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of congenital hypothyroidism and the image showing a mass protruding out of the umbilicus is indicative of an umbilical hernia. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition caused by an embryological defect in the thyroid gland or thyroid hormone synthesis.

Congenital hypothyroidism is commonly associated with other features such as:

  • Myxedematous facies
  • Large fontanelles
  • Macroglossia
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Hypotonia

Mayo’s operation is done for an umbilical hernia. Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia are:

  • Defect size >2cm
  • Persisting beyond 5 years
  • Progressively enlarging after 2 years of age (usually regresses spontaneously by 2 years of age)
  • Symptomatic
  • Strangulated

questions.text: A man is receiving a matched kidney allograft. While closing the abdomen, the surgeon notices a sudden change of color of transplanted kidney to pale-white. Which of the following is responsible for graft rejection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario within minutes of transplant is suggestive of hyperacute rejection and is due to preformed antibodies from the recipient. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

 

Mechanism

Morphology

T-cell-mediated

Acute

Seen within the initial months after transplantation;

Clinical and biochemical signs of organ failure;

Cytokines secreted by activated CD4+ T cells.

Increased vascular permeability and  accumulation of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes and macrophages)

Chronic

Lymphocytes reacting against alloantigens in the vessel wall

Cytokines that induce local inflammation and may stimulate the proliferation of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells.

The vascular lesions and T-cell reactions cause parenchymal fibrosis.

B-cell-mediated

  

Hyperacute

Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient

Endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi, Neutrophils, thrombotic occlusion of the capillaries, and fibrinoid necrosis in arterial walls

Acute antibody-mediated

Antidonor antibodies produced after transplantation

Complement-dependent cytotoxicity, inflammation, and antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.

The initial target of these antibodies in rejection seems to be the graft vasculature

Inflamation of capillaries

Deposition of the complement breakdown product C4d

Chronic antibody-mediated

Develops insidiously, without preceding acute rejection, and primarily affects vascular components.

  

 

Related Pearl: Transplant Rejection and Hypersensitivity

Type of Rejection  Type of Hypersensitivity
  • Host vs Graft
Hyperacute
Acute 
Chronic

 

Type 2
Type 4
Type 4
  • Graft vs Host
 Type 4

questions.text: In judicial hanging , the knot is placed at____________
questions.solution:
In judicial hanging ,the knot is placed at angle of jaw.

Judicial hanging

  • Face of the person is covered with dark mask ,he is made to stand on a platform above trapdoors ,which open downwards when blot is drawn.
  • Rope is looped around the neck and person is allowed to drop for 5-7 meters according to weight, age and build.
  • Sudden stop usually causes fracture dislocation at level C-2, C-3 or C-3  C-4 vertebra and rupture of brainstem between pons and medulla (hangman fracture).
  • Death is instantaneous but heartbeat may continue for 15-20 minutes and spasmodic muscle jerking may occur for considerable time.
  • Asphyxial signs are not seen in correctly performed judicial hangings.

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Trait

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Nature of death

Mostly suicidal

Mostly homicidal

Face

Usually pale and petechiae rare

Congested, livid and marked with petechiae

Tongue

Swelling and protrusion is less marked

Swelling and protrusion is more marked

Bleeding

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears not common

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears may be found

Saliva

Often dribbles out of the mouth

Such dribbling is very rare

Ligature mark

Oblique, non-continuous, placed high up in the neck between the chin and the larynx. 

The subcutaneous tissue underneath the mark is usually hard, white and glistening

Horizontal or transverse, continuous around the neck, low down in the neck below or across the thyroid.   

Subcutaneous tissue underneath may be ecchymosed

Abrasions and

ecchymoses

Rare

Common

Injury to muscles of

neck

Rare

Common

Carotid arteries

Internal coats usually ruptured in violent cases of a long drops(Amussat's sign)

Damage to internal coat is rare

Hyoid bone

Fracture of the hyoid bone less common

Fracture of the hyoid bone is uncommon (common in manual strangulation)

Thyroid cartilage

Fracture is less common

Fracture is more common

Cervical vertebrae

Fracture and/or dislocation common in judicial hanging

Fracture and/or dislocation—rare

questions.text: Pseudodementia is associated with which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Pseudodementia is a condition characterized by cognitive and functional impairment secondary to depression.

  • Dementia is defined as a disease process, which is marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Ex: Dementia in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Pseudodementia occurs in depressed people who complain of impaired memory but, in fact, have a depressive disorder.

The following table shows differentiating clinical features between dementia and pseudodementia:

Dementia

Pseudodementia

Clinical Course and History

 

Onset can be dated only within broad limits

Onset can be dated precisely

Long duration and slow progression of symptoms

Short duration and rapid progression of symptoms

Usually, there is no history of previous psychiatric dysfunction

There is a history of previous psychiatric dysfunction.

Family is not aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Family is aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Complaints and clinical behaviour

The patients complain little of cognitive loss, and the complaints are often vague

The patients complain much of cognitive loss, and the complaints are detailed.

Usually labile affect

  

Severe depression on examination

Disability is concealed by the patient

Disability is emphasized by the patient

Patient highlights accomplishments

Patient highlights failures

They struggle to perform simple tasks and rely on notes or calendars etc.

They make little effort to perform even simple tasks

Social skills are often retained

Loss of social skills often early and prominent
Behaviour is compatible with the severity of cognitive dysfunction Behaviour is incongruent with the severity of cognitive dysfunction
Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction common Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction uncommon

Clinical Features Related to Memory, Cognitive, and Intellectual Dysfunctions

Patient makes errors on cognitive examination

‘Do not know’ answers are more frequent

Attention and concentration usually faulty

 Attention and concentration often well preserved

Memory loss for recent events usually more severe than for remote events

  

Memory loss for recent and remote events usually severe

Memory gaps for specific periods unusual. Confabulation may be present.

  Memory gaps are usually present. Confabulation is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about port wine stain:
questions.solution:
Port wine stain is a congenital low-flow vascular malformation that does not fade away with time.

Port wine stains are congenital lesions that may occur anywhere in the body. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches.

Commonly they occur as isolated skin lesions but in rare cases, they are part of certain complex syndromes.

This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism. Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve is associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Features of port wine stain:

  • Does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tends to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

Given below is an image of port-wine stain:

questions.text: During a microbiology experiment, the gene for diphtheria toxin from Corynebacterium diphtheriae is carried on corynebacteriophages, and the toxin is produced only by the bacteria that are lysogenized by the phages. Which of the following methods of horizontal gene transfer is outlined in the above example?
questions.solution:
The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
The most commonly affected site in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

Other commonly affected sites in Crohn's disease include the small intestine and the colon. Although it can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared.

On the other hand, the rectum is almost always involved in ulcerative colitis.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

Smoking 

Appendicectomy

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a long bone fracture following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is fat embolism. 

Fat embolism is caused by the fat globules originating from the bone marrow following the fracture of long bones. 

Clinical features of fat embolism are usually seen within 72 hours. They include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness.

There is no specific test for diagnosis. However, urine analysis to look for fat globules and monitoring of blood pO2 are done. Management of fat embolism is mostly supportive, with oxygen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Air embolism occurs when air bubbles entering the pulmonary circulation get absorbed in large quantities. Severe hypotension and hypoxemia are seen in this condition. The patient is placed in Trendelenburg's left lateral decubitus position. 

Option C: Venous thromboembolism consists of pulmonary embolism (PE) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Bedridden patients and patients with chronic systemic diseases are more prone to thromboembolism. Clinical features of PE include dyspnea, syncope, cyanosis, hypotension, etc. DVT is presented as leg cramps, erythema, and tenderness. Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux are used for the treatment. 

Option D: Pulmonary hypertension is a disease that involves the remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature. It results in increased pulmonary artery pressure and vascular resistance. It mainly occurs as a complication of left heart disease, other primary lung diseases, and pulmonary embolism. The clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, syncope, etc.
